solutions architecture team for US state and local government prior to joining AWS about two years ago
I spent about 15 years in higher education in a number of IT leadership
roles so I wanted to give you just a little bit of overview of what we're gonna talk
about today and what to expect about this session so this is a 200 level
session so the expectation is that you you've very familiar with the cloud and
some of AWS is availability zones and regions but we're gonna talk about some
of the services that are really relevant to hybrid the expectation is that you're
not super deep and the this discussion is not going to go very deep technically
so hopefully that that's the right session you're looking for today we are not going to be talking about the VMware
announcement that we made recently that's a different session so most hopefully everyone's in the right place
today we're going to cover the AWS services that really help you to achieve hybrid cloud as well as a customer use
case for hybrid and then I'm gonna show a couple of demos along the way to give you a good feel of how the AWS
environment works so someone told me once that it's best
to start a presentation with words from somebody who's much smarter than you in this case I chose weren't
the quote here I think is really salient because it talks about how AWS isn't
building an all-or-nothing environment but rather we're empowering customers to
have choice so if you have an investment in on-prem infrastructure that you want to continue to leverage but you also
want to take advantage of the scalability and the cost benefits of the cloud we have a lot of services that
will help you cheat both
so I want to start by talking about a customer's journey to AWS they
approached me and said look we we really want to take advantage of AWS for the
flexibility of starting new resources for the scalability of growing into services that we need as well as some of
the cost benefits we also want to empower our customers our end users to
have flexibility with how they access our services whether that's from our own network or if that's from their home
using their own device BYOD so this particular customer is a large
public sector customer very much like most of you today there's a central IT
team that handles a lot of the core infrastructure networking facilities servers and then there's IT
departments within the business units and departments that are really building and maintaining the line of business IT
systems so we're working with this customer and
we'd say ok let's let's focus down on one application because there's a lot of
moving parts with a very large organization and so it's best to start small build some momentum build some
competency and some excitement and then get bigger so this is what the customers
environment looked like at least this one portion of the application we were talking about it was Active Directory
that maintained all of the user identity there was a file server for maintaining
all of the files and then a number of Windows desktops that were connecting to that Windows file server so this is
pretty standard pretty simple workload but what it does is it shows how simple something can be and how we can take
that and translate it to the cloud in a very easy but very robust way
so when I start talking with customers who have a lot of moving parts and a lot of workloads typically we say ok let's
take a step and talk about identity identity is important because we don't want to have a proliferation of
different identity stores different users it's very difficult to manage and so AWS provides a lot of services to
help manage identity in the cloud so let's start that conversation with
the customer we talked about I am which is our Identity and Access Management Service this service provides fine-grain
control of all of your cloud-based resources so if you have a group of
users that are your system administrators you can provide roles and policies that allow those system
administrators to manage servers and then you can provide other policies to allow your network administrators to
manage the network and infrastructure and the to can't change each other's work and so you can create that
separation of duties within your cloud environment just like you have on-premise today
not only that but we can take identity access management and integrate that with your on-premises Active Directory
so if you want to take that corporate directory that identity store you already have you can leverage those user
identities passwords and use that account to access your resources in AWS
we also provide the ability to use multi-factor authentication so for those
users who have the ability to create and destroy resources inside of AWS it's
often a good idea to lock those down to make sure that you know who those users are and you use two-factor
authentication to do that that's supported inside of I am I am also supports Federation so if
you're using an ad FS server today or another sam'l provider or if you're
leveraging your identity store from Amazon Facebook Google or any other open ID provider you can integrate those
identities with iam so that again you have that single source of truth across both platforms
another great service that AWS provides is the directory service so this comes
in three flavors there's Microsoft Active Directory which is a fully managed Active
Directory environment from Windows Microsoft we also have simple ad which is a Microsoft
compatible directory leveraging samba and then we have the ad connector which
is a proxy to your on-premises Active Directory all three of these are delivered as the managed service so you
don't have to worry about patching your environment or doing backups all of that's handled for you
the value of leveraging the directory service in addition to being simple is that it allows you to join servers or
instances running inside of AWS to your directory very seamlessly it also allows
you to do single sign-on to your AWS console and other applications within
the cloud so what I wanted to do next will show you a demo of how easy it is to create a
managed Microsoft Active Directory inside of AWS and I'm gonna do a demo we
were gonna do a live demo but there's something always goes around with technology usually it's my fault so I
will own that but today we did a recording to show you exactly what this looks like the other benefit of the
recording is that I can fast forward some of the wait time because as you're spinning up resources in the cloud
sometimes it takes five or ten minutes for a resource to get created and configured all that happens in the
background so I'm gonna be able to scrub out that extra time today so this this demo is going to go through creating a
Microsoft Active Directory then configuring that Active Directory to use sign-on directly to the AWS
console so I usually show customers this because it really demonstrates the power of how simple and easy things can be
with an AWS so first what I'm gonna do here is click on Microsoft ad one of the three options
and then I'm going to define my Active Directory domain name this is the fully
qualified domain name reinvent demo as is mine for today after I enter the NetBIOS name you'll

know ahead of time there might be charges so that you don't get an unexpected bill so now um you can see

URL is my unique URL name to get to my EWS resources for
this directory so first we create that and then it updates all the DNS records
and after that we need to go create and configure the roles and the users that

console access and then we're gonna create a role
now again earlier I said you can do fine-grain access so you can create

that you can make this very granular as you can see there's a couple of pre-built pre-canned options I'm gonna
choose power user because after all this is my admin user
so next I have to search for either an Active Directory group or an Active
Directory user that I want to associate with this role and the permissions that they'll have in AWS so I've selected my
admin user I'm gonna assign them to the role and now I'll be able to use the
credentials from my admin user running in Active Directory to authenticate to the AWS console
so next I need to grab the sign in URL from the directory and then I'll right-click on that and open it up in a
new tab and now you can see that I can log in with my admin user that I created for ad
and the password
so that's as simple and easy as it is to create a fully managed Active Directory
environment inside of AWS and then begin leveraging those users to sign into the
console so if you wanted to leverage that as your single source of truth for all of your applications running in the
cloud it's that easy so now that we've talked through
identity and the customer really understands how to manage their identity in both their on-premise and in the
cloud we said okay let's before we do anything else let's make sure we back up our data do you have a good backup of
your your data before we start making any architectural changes and are you confident that you have access to that
is that in a tape that's stored halfway around the world is that on Prem where is that and so
we first said okay let's let's make sure we have a good backup strategy for that data that we had access to today
so we first started talking about some of the services that really help that customer do backups when you think of
backups to AWS the first thing that comes to mind is object-based storage it's very inexpensive and extremely
durable we have three tiers of storage we have our s3 or simple storage service
we have s3 infrequent access and then we have Amazon glacier all three are
designed for 11 nines of durability which is a fancy way of saying if you
took 10,000 objects and put them into the store you may lose one object every
10 million years or so so this is a very durable place to put your data you can
rest assured that when you put your data into the service you can get it back out again which is really the point
in addition to the three-tier so really the three tiers offer you different availability
s3 is really for your hot data where you want to frequently interact with infrequent access is better for data
that you may not need to access very often but when you do you don't want to
wait for it you want to have immediate access to that data and then glacier is for your colder archival data data that
you probably won't need to access very frequently and if you do need to get it
back you can wait for a couple of hours and as you move through the tiers the cost goes down and so you can take the
right choice of storage tier to meet your particular use case
we also have the import/export snowball this is great for moving large amounts
of data into AWS so if you have many terabytes or even petabytes of data
AWS can ship you one of these devices that will arrive on your your network
and your data center and then you can begin doing a very fast local data transfer to that device the device
encrypts all of the data with 256 bit AES encryption and you can track that
device as it leaves your data center and travels through the carrier to AWS and
then AWS will load that data directly into your s3 bucket where you'll have access to it so if you're if you're
managing multiple petabytes of data upload this is a great service to get
you going the other cool thing is it's very rugged we did a demo where you can pick it up and just drop it onto the
floor so it can survive the calamities of of carrier
so this particular customer was using CommVault backup software which was very
convenient because conve it has native integration with s3 so we were able to very seamlessly retarget their backups
to an s3 bucket of their in their account and begin backing up all of
their data directly to s3 over the internet then we built some life cycle policies
so that as they're going they can start tearing data down to lower cost storage over time
I also want to talk to you today about the Storage Gateway because I think the has a great use case for hybrid cloud so
the storage gateway is of virtual appliance it gets deployed on hyper-v or VMware in your own data center and it
creates a logical drive or a logical volume with an ice cozy target so we
have three modes of this one is stored which means that you have a one to one relationship between the storage on the
the logical storage that's represented with the storage on your Sam cached mode
is reduces the footprint of storage you need to have on Prem and keeps your hot
data locally on that storage but then tears everything else all the cold data
off to s3 and then the virtual tape library mode or VTL is for use with your
backup software as a replacement for tape so I'm sure everybody here loves
managing tapes keeping tapes in your environment having to swap them in and out call to get them back when you need
one for recovery so the virtual tape library really simplifies that entire
workflow and of course all of the storage from the from the storage
gateway is backed by s3 so you're gaining the durability of that 11 nines of durability
so in this case this is what this looks like you have of the storage gateway in cache mode running inside of your data
center with an iSCSI target presented back to your file server and then you
can reduce the amount of sand storage you would need locally this wasn't really an issue for this customer but I
presented it as options when you're putting together your migration strategy so we didn't do this but it was
definitely an option that could have taken advantage of
parmie so now that we've got backup of all of the customers data and we
understand how we're gonna manage identities the next thing to do is make sure we have connectivity between their
data center and the AWS network so networking is extremely important
this becomes your conduit to get data back and forth so the first service that AWS offers
really the core is the V PC this is your virtual private cloud you can think of this as your own virtual data center
running inside of AWS it's really a logical isolation of all of your resources and it contains a lot of the
same networking constructs that you would expect to see in your own data center so you have the ability to create
subnets you have the ability to create Network ACLs route tables and even a
stateful firewalls we call them security groups you can extend your IP scheme into the V
PC so that it's consistent with your existing site or ranges that you're using on your own network
really there's three different ways to connect to that V PC from your own network one is over the Internet using a
proxy or a bastion host more commonly customers choose to use a VPN a Howard
based VPN or a direct connect in this particular case this customer chose to use a direct connect
so a Direct Connect is a dedicated network connection between your network
and AWS and your V PC gives you that consistent networking performance and we
can deliver this in speeds of 50 megabits all the way up to 10 gigabits per second
and you can have multiple pathways so you can have redundancy in case there's a failure
so now we're starting to build an architecture we have the existing
customer environment we have the network connectivity and we have a V PC
so that's great but we need to do something with this we just have all of this underlying
infrastructure now we need to start layering and compute so
ec2 are Elastic Compute cloud is a virtual servers running inside of AWS we
give you the keys you're in control you can spin up new servers and destroy servers delete them as your needs
dictate and it's flexible you can choose to have a very small server one CPU or a
couple of gigabytes of memory and you can go to very large servers you know hundreds of CPUs so you have a lot of
range in the complement of hardware that you're able to take advantage of and not
only that but you can change your instance type as your needs change so if you start a small server that's very
small and use that for testing and then as the demand and the usage of that server increases over time you can
change out the underlying hardware to give you more performance
the service is also delivered using standard operating systems so Windows
Server as well as various flavors of Linux so if and we have a number of
different versions of Windows so there's some backwards compatibility as well
so the customer is very excited now right they they see all this infrastructure they're ready to go let's
pick up that file server and just hand it to us AWS you take that file server you're often running well number one we
can't take their file server but we can import a virtual machine so we could take that virtual file server running on
premise and then we can move it and import it into AWS and so that would
look like this right boom move the file server over you have network connectivity your clients can connect to
that file server everything works just fine however there's a gotcha
windows SMB is extremely sensitive to latency and so while this would probably
work you may end up introducing some poor performance and a poor experience
for your customers and we don't want to do that and so the solutions architects understand some of
these constraints and so we make recommendations that say for this particular use case that may work fine
where you have maybe one or two users and you're just using that as a backup
target but in this particular case they had a lot of users who were accessing that file server and we were concerned that
they would have a poor performance and we didn't want to set them up for failure so we said okay that's great but stop please don't do that we have a
different design pattern that will work better for your use case and so this
design pattern gives the customer a couple of things number one and really the most important it gives them high
availability so if there's a failure from their on-premises data center there's a fire
they had a hardware failure they'd have to recover those servers and
everyone has different disaster recovery plans but sometimes disaster recovery plans can take hours days to implement
and they're expensive if you want to shorten that time frame so in this particular case what we're recommending
is the customer make a copy of their Active Directory domain controller and run it inside of AWS so now they have to
and they can replicate those together so they have an extension of their
on-premises Active Directory Network now they have Active Directory running both
on-premises and an AWS and then we can join the AWS directory service to that
so that we have access to join other servers to the domain and leverage that
directory for single sign-on to the AWS resources so next we add on an layer on a file
server this is a Windows 2012 file server looking just like the file server running on Prem in their data center and
then we configure DFS replication and that's really the magic sauce and I say
magic sauce but it's built into Windows so when you're running a file server you add a new role and you can point your
existing file server at the new one and they will begin replicating all of the data from the local data center file
server will replicate to the file server running inside of AWS and they will keep themselves in so changes made on one
side will always be reflected on the other now the value of this is that while your users can connect to the
local file server they're not connecting across that link to the other file server and so the
latency between those servers can be a little bit higher but DFS kind of mitigates that for you because it's not
going to impact the direct end user during that synchronization

so what if we now take that same concept of the storage gateway and put that into
AWS our customer said no I really love this
whole thing but I'm really cost conscious we need to make sure that we're really reducing cost as much as
possible and I'm concerned about just making sure that everything is working correctly so we introduced the concept
of putting the Storage Gateway inside of the V PC again we can put this in cache
mode so we're only leveraging a small amount of SSD storage on the instance
and then pushing the rest of that storage up to s3 there's some trade-offs here that you
have to be aware of so we're gonna reduce cost by switching from SSD to s3
and we're gonna increase durability however there's a trade-off in performance and so he has to be the
right use case so if this file server has lots of large files and a lot of the
files are cold and won't be accessed very frequently you can still get very good experience through the store
Gateway however if you're expecting a lot of really high i/o you probably want
to keep that storage on SSD to get the performance so it really again comes back to the use case and that's where
the solutions architects really help with this we can help talk through the
use case that you have understand what your requirements are and make suggestions about how we can optimize
your environment given the different tooling that are available so in this particular case the customer
chose to leverage the storage gateway which had a significant cost savings for them
so for their 20 terabyte file server on the left-hand side here you can see that
the storage cost for EBS storage was about two thousand dollars so their overall cost for running that file
server and storage was twenty three hundred and sixty-two dollars however by introducing the storage gateway and
tearing a lot of that storage off to s 3 they were able to lower their costs to
about $1,300 so that's a significant savings now I'm giving you these numbers
I was illustrative purposes because some of this changes right there's there's
variation with the amount of storage consumed you can also leverage our reserved instances for pricing to reduce
some of that cost so this is all our on-demand pricing but I wanted to give you an example of what that savings
could look like for a 20 terabyte file server
so next we wanted to tackle the BYOD challenge the customer says okay it's

Windows desktop as a service so it's a completely managed you can click a button and spin up a virtual server
pretty easily and we have clients that support Mac
Windows iOS Android and even a new web-based client
so now that we've layered in workspaces now that this customers end users have

on demand because you need to get an understanding of your usage and your customers usage as you're working with

of services configured then you can get reserved instances to lower your cost the real value here is that we often
over provision I'm guilty of it I used to throw a lot
of hardware at a problem and never tested thoroughly and so with AWS you have the ability to really hone in on
the right amount of hardware to solve the problem and so if you can go from a server that has 16 CPUs down to a server
that has 4 CPUs you have significant cost savings and you'll only know that
by spinning up the environment inside of AWS and testing it
so while that was where they're at that's not the end of the story so if
the customer at some point has completely amortized their investment in their on-premises data center and they

you know getting out of that it's really expensive Colo facility is is a driver
